steps.description: Customer notices slow broadband, opens the the provider Media app, and runs in-app diagnostics.
steps.businessRationale: Launching the app, authenticating, and running diagnostics typically takes 5–7 minutes; effective self-service can prevent costly support calls and engineer visits.

steps.description: Customer initiates live chat with support to troubleshoot slow speeds after diagnostics show an issue.
steps.businessRationale: Typical broadband chat sessions last 10–20 minutes; resolving issues in chat reduces churn risk and avoids higher-cost phone support.

steps.description: Support agent schedules an engineer visit through the booking system and confirms details with the customer.
steps.businessRationale: Checking engineer availability, confirming address, and booking a slot typically takes 8–12 minutes; efficient scheduling minimizes downtime and customer frustration.

steps.description: Engineer visits the customer premises, diagnoses the network issue, and restores normal broadband performance.
steps.businessRationale: Onsite visits typically last 45–60 minutes; successful first-time fix is critical to reducing repeat visits, support costs, and churn.

steps.description: Customer verifies improved speeds via app or browser test and confirms service restoration.
steps.businessRationale: Running speed tests and confirming stability typically takes 8–10 minutes; verification ensures the issue is resolved and reduces repeat contacts.

steps.description: Customer receives follow-up message confirming resolution and is invited to complete a satisfaction survey.
steps.businessRationale: Follow-up communication and a short survey typically take 3–5 minutes; positive satisfaction scores correlate with reduced churn and higher lifetime value.
